Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle around my neck, scanning the water for any sign of trouble. My little sister, Mia, was sitting on the bleachers, her face streaked with tears. She’d just had a fight with her best friend, and I could see her shoulders shaking as she tried to hide her sobs. As her brother, I wanted nothing more than to rush over, sit beside her, and let her know I was there for her, just like Mom always said we should. But as the only lifeguard on duty, I couldn’t leave my post. At the same time, a group of kids started slipping into the shallow end without waiting for me to check the area, breaking the rules I was supposed to enforce. My supervisor expected me to keep everyone safe, no exceptions. I felt torn—my sister needed me, but so did the swimmers. My heart pounded as I gripped the whistle, caught between the urge to comfort Mia and the responsibility to keep the pool safe.
